content.text: State the time when the ball reaches the start of the rough section of the horizontal surface

Using Fig. 1.1, determine the acceleration of the ball as it rolls down the ramp
acceleration =   .........
The ball starts from rest at the top of the ramp
Show that the length of the ramp is \(9.6 \text{m}\)

A ball rolls down a ramp and onto a horizontal surface. The first section of the horizontal surface is smooth. The second section of the horizontal surface is rough. Fig. 1.1 shows a speed–time graph for the ball

The reading on the spring balance is 8.0 kg
Determine the force exerted on the spring due to the baby
The limit of proportionality for the spring is at a force of \(175 \text{N}\)
Sketch the extension–load graph for the spring. The sketch must continue beyond a force of \(175 \text{N}\)
The baby is carried from the ground floor to the bedroom. The vertical height of the bedroom above the ground floor is \(3.5 \text{m}\)
Calculate the change in gravitational potential energy of the baby when it is carried from the ground floor to the bedroom
change in gravitational potential energy = ...............................................

Fig. 2.1 shows a spring balance used to measure the weight of a baby. The spring inside the balance extends when a mass is suspended from it. The dial shows the extension of spring as a value of mass in kg
The spring obeys Hooke's law up to a weight of \(175 \text{N}\)
Describe the process by which the volume of water in the puddle decreases

statement
explanation

Calculate the mass of the sample of sand
Calculate the thermal capacity of the sample of sand
thermal capacity =   .........
The initial temperature of the sample of sand is \(7.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The sample of sand is heated using an electrical heater. The power of the heating element is \(50\mathrm{W}\)
Calculate the time taken to increase the temperature of the sand to \(19.0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)

A sample of sand has a volume of \(0.050 \text{m}^3\). The density of the sand is \(1900 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\). The specific heat capacity of the sand is \(1500 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)
Describe, in terms of molecules, how thermal energy is transferred from the heated sand through the base of the plastic pot
The heating element in Fig. 4.1 remains switched on. The temperature of the sand remains constant at a value above room temperature
Explain why the temperature of the sand remains constant

In some countries, the soil is too cold for plants to grow well. In these countries, plants are grown in plastic pots and kept inside. The pots, containing soil, are placed on sand. The sand is heated using an electrical heater, as shown in Fig. 4.1

number of cells =   .........

Complete the nuclide equation for this decay
Describe how the americium-241 ionises air
Suggest and explain two reasons why smoke detectors use an isotope that emits \(\alpha\) -particles rather than an isotope that emits \(\gamma\) -radiation
Fig. 10.1 shows a simple diagram of a smoke detector. The smoke detector contains a small sample of americium-241. This isotope ionises the air between the metal plates in the detector
The isotope americium-241 is represented by
This isotope decays by an \(\alpha\)-emission to an isotope of neptunium (Np)
